As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts: My neighborhood is a melting pot, with residential areas scattered throughout a vast landscape of commercial spaces. Amidst the hustle and bustle, a diverse array of businesses thrive. You can find offices, stores, restaurants, and entertainment venues, all vying for attention in a sea of choice. With numerous eateries to try and shops to explore, it's easy to get caught up in the endless options. The mix of big-box stores and small boutiques is a defining feature of our neighborhood, with some lining the streets and others tucked away in local malls. The presence of nearby parks adds a touch of tranquility, attracting families with young children who come to enjoy the green spaces. As for the people, our neighborhood is a microcosm of the city's diversity. One area is home to a thriving LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a cluster of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Just a short drive away, other communities of various racial and ethnic backgrounds are scattered throughout the city, each with their own distinct neighborhoods like Korea town, China town, and Little Armenia. However, the city's massive size and notorious traffic congestion often make even short drives feel like a marathon. With traffic jams a regular occurrence, especially during rush hour, it's no wonder that walking is a rare sight. Despite being close to various points of interest, the city's sheer size and poor traffic make it a chore to get around on foot. The irony is that despite the city's appeal, it's also a hub of construction, with new apartment buildings sprouting up everywhere. This has sparked concerns among residents, who worry about the impact of growing crowds and increased traffic. Our neighborhood is a varied landscape of homes, with single-family houses, duplexes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums all jostling for space. Even within our immediate neighborhood, there's a range of housing options to suit different tastes and preferences. Similarly, the neighborhood is home to people of all ages, and I have to admit that I'm not familiar with most of my neighbors. While it's not the tight-knit community it once was, I do have fond memories of childhood summers spent playing with my next-door neighbor and a few close friends from the neighborhood, who all shared a similar age.

My neighborhood is a treasure trove of nostalgia, where the quintessential American dream still lingers in the air.  Many of the houses are single-family homes, but a few have been transformed into double residences, still connected but distinct, if you will. My home has a small front yard and a driveway to the left, evoking memories of a bygone era when suburban living was the epitome of the American ideal.  However, this dream seems to be slowly slipping away, and the once-ubiquitous optimism is waning. Yet, my neighborhood and others like it still beckon, a testament to the enduring power of this ideal. The residents, though less optimistic than in the past, still take pride in their homes, and the upkeep may not be what it used to be, but there are still cars in every driveway, and the youth still play with abandon, oblivious to the world beyond their little patch of grass. The local public school, a stalwart presence for nearly a century, continues to inspire the young and stir nostalgia in the old-timers. The churches, though fewer and farther between, still stand as beacons of community, while the basketball courts remain a hub of activity. Despite the unique facades, each home feels familiar, like a comforting old friend. Our neighborhood is a melting pot, with a diverse array of residents, including a large Yemeni family who own the local supermarket, "Super A," which is a rare oasis in an African American-dominated area. The streets are wide, and football reigns supreme, with the kids only pausing to let cars pass. Many residents have lived here for generations, and their collective memories paint a picture of a bygone era where everyone knew each other. A karate school once stood, but when the fad passed, it was reborn as a pharmacy, a testament to the ever-changing tides of popularity. Our neighborhood is also home to a small, old-school movie theater that screens classic films at a bargain price, a haven for the elderly who cherish the simple pleasures in life. The local youth may dismiss it as outdated, but the elders see it as a priceless gem. We have a single expressway that passes through our town, but the entrance and exit are conveniently located in the adjacent town, sparing us from the chaos. There was a time when the youth and elders were at odds over a proposal to bring an exit to our town, with the youth advocating for convenience and the elders fearing the consequences of growth. They prevailed, and now a new high school is on the horizon, with the task of choosing a mascot that embodies our community's unique spirit. I think a cyborg with a country twang and a log cabin would be the perfect representation of our town's quirks and charms.

Behind a row of shopping centers, you might easily miss it - a residential area that seems unassuming and unremarkable.  It's an unlikely place to find a thriving community, but if you venture beyond the old, abandoned Whole Foods and the annual-occupancy hotels that fill up during family reunions, you'll discover a vibrant neighborhood tucked away from the main road.  Nestled next to each other like intricately designed puzzle pieces are a series of apartment complexes, each one a testament to the layering of lives and experiences that have made this place home.  While one complex has garnered attention for less-than-savory reasons, the ones beside it and those that follow are a different story altogether - a world hidden in plain sight, unknown to many who pass through this area every day.  Across from these apartment complexes stands a community college satellite campus, its sleepy buildings standing guard over the road as students shuffle in with coffee in hand, still yawning at the early morning hour.  The iron gates slowly open to let them in, while commuters on the outside shake their fists at the delay, frustrated by the traffic congestion that ensues when classes are in session.  The road splits, merging with another residential street lined with a park and a rehabilitation center that offers a beacon of hope for those who need it.  The center's porch furniture exudes warmth, and its ceiling fan lazily circulates the warm summer air, creating a soothing atmosphere.  Children play in the park across the street, their laughter and shouts filling the air as they spin and twirl on the grass.  Bees flit about the flower patches, adding a touch of vibrancy to the scene.  Retirees stroll their dogs along the walking path, casting disapproving glances at the teenagers on skateboards while nodding politely at the teenage girls chatting by the playground equipment.  A sushi restaurant in the adjacent strip mall offers affordable eats that rarely draw a crowd, while a swimming supply store and nail salon sit nearby, catering to the community's diverse needs.  You could stock your pool for the season and get a manicure, all while indulging in hibachi chicken - the embodiment of a strip mall's convenience.  A frozen yogurt shop, where teens often grab a cooling treat, is also part of this thriving neighborhood, where time stands still and the rhythms of life unfold at a leisurely pace.

As we cruised down the two-lane country road, the endless corn fields stretching as far as the eye could see were a stark contrast to the urban jungle she called home.  She had grown up just a stone's throw from the local grocery store, so the vast expanse of countryside left her awestruck.  I chuckled, knowing she was struggling to comprehend the simplicity of rural life.  I shared with her my own experiences growing up in rural Ohio, and it was as if a lightbulb went off - she finally understood me and my roots.  The road wound on, passing a quarry filled with water, before eventually leading to my neighborhood.  The houses here were a mix of brick and stucco, each one standing proudly on at least half an acre of meticulously maintained land.  During the spring, vibrant flowers bloomed alongside the ever-changing midwestern trees, their beauty a reflection of the passing seasons.  The driveways were lined with sleek Mercedes-Benz luxury cars that sparkled in the sunlight after a refreshing wash.  My neighbor, a kind-hearted Korean man, was always tending to his lawn, his friendly face a familiar sight.  He would spend the entire day mowing, his singing voice carrying above the hum of his John Deere Zero Turn mower, bringing a smile to everyone's face.  As he's aged, his wit has mellowed, but his genuine nature remains.  His past as a doctor is a testament to his remarkable character.  Eventually, we arrived at my home, surrounded by geese that my Terrier chased with gusto.  A small stream ran through the backyard, feeding into the quarry, and the sounds of bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional distant "moo" from the nearby farms filled the air.  Across the handmade wooden bridge lay an untouched oasis, teeming with wildflowers, herbs, and towering trees.  This was my childhood playground, where I spent countless hours building tree forts, "hunting" imaginary prey, and forging friendships with the neighborhood kids.  The winters were harsh, but also breathtakingly beautiful, transforming the yard from a lush green oasis to a frozen wilderness.  The trees stood bare, their vibrant flowers a distant memory, but the occasional snowfall would paint the scene with a serene beauty.  My sister and I would create an army of snowmen and snow angels, our rivalry turning into a friendly competition.  We'd build igloo-like forts, stockpiling branches and snowballs, our winter wonderland a place where nothing else mattered, just the simplicity of childhood and the joy of imagination.

To truly grasp the essence of Portland, Oregon, you have to understand the essence of the term 'weird'. The unofficial motto, scribbled on a building that serves as a multitude of establishments including a pizza joint, bar, music venue, and strip club, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this phrase represents a nostalgic longing for the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's - a time when the city was less known, less expensive, and fostered one-of-a-kind subcultures. For others, it's an invitation - come to Portland, where being different is not just accepted, but celebrated. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the relentless construction of condominiums to cater to them, Portland remains an eccentric city. Portland's 'weirdness' doesn't mean it's always open-minded, but it does signify a willingness to accept the unconventional. We have our modern conveniences and modern problems like everyone else, purchasing most of our goods from China. There are many ways to be unusual, to be anything but ordinary, but Portland also has its share of standard. Our city boasts yoga enthusiasts, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps 'weird' simply means we take it all less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, you'll find vibrant houses, luscious home gardens, and free boxes lining the streets during the summer. These free boxes can hold anything from clothes and books to treasures beyond imagination. The magic lies in discovering what you might find, which is often a delightful surprise. That's the essence of Portland, at least to me - a city where the unexpected is the norm. However, I'm just one of the thousands of 'weird' Portlanders, and my perspective is but a reflection of the vast diversity that exists in our city. Some people I live among wouldn't dream of rummaging through a box on the sidewalk for clothes, and they instead opt for goat yoga or Timbers matches. Portland is teeming with individuals who pursue their passions, or fantasize about doing so while spending too much time at the local bar. Yes, Portland struggles with a drug problem, which often stems from underlying mental health issues. The constant rain and grey skies that dominate much of the year don't help. We also have a homelessness problem, which is a complex issue that no one seems to have a clear solution for. The homeless population is drawn to our social services, which are better than those in many other parts of the country. However, our resources are insufficient, a problem that plagues every city. The non-homeless population is torn between empathy and hostility, and in this regard, we're not so different from the rest of the world.

They're always there, silently standing tall in the north, watching the sun rise and set, a constant presence that knows no bounds.  No matter how consumed I am with life's chaos or preoccupied with the tasks that never seem to end, they remain steadfast, unwavering, and unyielding to the turmoil that surrounds me.  It's on the most trying days, when anxiety threatens to overwhelm me, that they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them, they offer a tranquil respite, infusing me with the strength to face another day.  My journey here began during my university days, and it was the northern mountains that initially captivated me.  While the campus boasts its own share of breathtaking views in its buildings, ponds, and trees, which hold a special place in my heart, the mountains hold a unique throne.  The town itself is a charming blend of old and new, with quaint cafés where countless hours were spent over steaming cups of coffee during all-night cram sessions.  A short walk or bus ride takes you to the downtown area, where the faded brick facades of restaurants and office buildings transport you to a bygone era, mirroring the energy of the nearby city.  This dichotomy of atmospheres so close together creates a captivating aura that beckons exploration, making it easy to form lasting memories in association with different parts of town.  Whether it's strolling past the rusty swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or racing through the bustling downtown to catch a movie in the university-provided theater, this place has been a canvas for many cherished recollections.  However, it's also a place where harsh memories reside, as they do in every place we call home.  The ponds, in particular, have been a sanctuary for introspection and, at times, cathartic release, especially during the darkest hours of the night.  As I watched the turtles, ducks, and insects living their lives, each contributing in their own way, I couldn't help but ponder my own purpose in the grand scheme of things.  I'd walk past the pond, the park, and the houses that scream of suburban comfort, until I reached the main street.  It was then that the sun broke through the clouds, casting its golden rays upon the palm trees, painting the sky with hues of blue and yellow.  As I gazed up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north.  And there they were, standing tall, their rugged presence stirring a sense of determination within me, a reminder that I had only to look to them to find the strength to keep moving forward.

Those venturing to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, will find it's easily accessible by public transportation, a staple in New York City. As a fairly urban neighborhood, you'll still get a taste of what it's like to be in the Big Apple. Be prepared to be surrounded by Asian stores and shops on nearly every block, a testament to the neighborhood's influx of Asian residents over the past two decades. You'll find Asian-owned supermarkets and laundromats are particularly prevalent, and for good reason - they offer quality food at affordable prices, with added convenience. Just a stone's throw from my current location, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walk of each other, making grocery shopping a breeze.

While Bensonhurst is predominantly Asian, it's not homogenous, with a diverse mix of immigrants, first- and second-generation Americans, and their families. Many of the large and popular businesses are Asian-owned, but you'll also find other establishments and attractions in the area. A nearby park offers a haven for recreation, featuring ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, a playground for kids, and a water fountain for kids to enjoy during the summer months. As with many New York City parks, this one is a melting pot of cultures, where people from all walks of life come together in harmony.

You won't find any high-rise corporate buildings in this neighborhood; instead, you'll see co-op living spaces and condominium apartments, with the majority of residents living in two-family homes. While people in Bensonhurst are generally friendly, they can be quite vocal with their cars, often blasting music or accelerating loudly, which can be jarring to some. As with any urban neighborhood, especially in New York City, be cautious at night, as you may encounter individuals looking for trouble. I've personally experienced bullying and package theft in the past, so it's essential to be on your guard. Dog owners also seem to be lax about picking up after their pets, so be prepared to navigate dog waste on the sidewalks and streets. With a little caution and awareness, you'll be able to navigate Bensonhurst with ease, but don't say I didn't warn you!

Living in my area can be a bit unforgiving, as the terrain slopes steeply downward, placing my house at the apex of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. Locals have even dubbed it the "workout hill" due to the numerous joggers who run up it daily. With no sidewalks on my street, pedestrians share the road, which often poses a hazard due to its pitted surface and the presence of overhanging telephone and electric wires that seem to sag under the weight of frequent repairs after storms. The abundance of evergreen trees around us is often met with disdain by residents, who seek to cut them down to preserve the ocean views, which have become a prized feature of the high-slung houses built along the hillside. These structures feature expansive glass-fronted second stories that offer a panoramic view of the bay. While the sunsets can be breathtaking, especially when the water appears to be lit from below and the sky transforms into a kaleidoscope of oranges, the area's overcast climate typically shrouds the scenery in a haze. Moisture-laden days are the norm, resulting in an environment where moss thrives on any surface it can cling to – roofs, cars, and railings alike. I recall leaving my car parked in the driveway for a month, only to return and find it covered in a thick layer of moss and lichen, requiring an arduous three-hour scrubbing session to remove. The neighborhood's demographics lean towards retirees, with children scarce, but dogs make up for it, often roaming freely in people's lawns or racing down the street. Their curious nature means that leaving doors or windows open can invite unwanted visitors, as I once discovered when I found a stray dog in my living room. Rabbits also roam freely, wreaking havoc on gardens and lawns, but my cats have been instrumental in keeping their numbers under control. The skies above us are home to an assortment of birds, including sparrows, hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle, which is chased away by the vigilant crows. While there are no local stores, venturing downhill to the waterfront reveals a few eateries serving fresh seafood, and the rocky shoreline offers a fun spot to skip stones into the water. The bay is relatively narrow, making the opposite shoreline visible even on misty days.

I reside in a typical suburban setting in a small Tennessee town, situated on a street that serves as a connector between two state highways. While this means our street gets a moderate amount of traffic, it's otherwise a quiet neighborhood. With a relatively low turnover of residents, I've grown accustomed to knowing most of the folks who call this place home. On any given day, you can find people tending to their lawns or attending to their daily chores. In the winter, our side street becomes a popular spot for sledding, and our house, positioned at the front corner of the street, offers a front-row seat to the comings and goings of the neighborhood. When a stranger's vehicle appears, it's often met with a raised eyebrow, as we've grown accustomed to recognizing the familiar faces and rides of our neighbors. Some take to walking for exercise or to stroll their dogs, while kids can be seen cruising on their bikes, enjoying the simple pleasures of suburban life. Since my family and I work from home, we spend a lot of time here, and I'd say our presence has become a familiar sight to the others. We love getting outside, even on rainy days, and occasionally fire up the grill on our back deck, filling the air with the savory scent of barbecue. The neighborhood is dotted with trees, a relic of its former life as a wooded area, providing ample shade during the warmer months. However, this also means a chorus of lawn mowers echoes through the air from March to October, when the grass finally stops growing. As the seasons change, the leaves fall, and the annual ritual of raking and burning them begins. I must admit, I find the smell of burning leaves quite endearing, signaling the arrival of fall. Lately, our winters have been scarce, and it feels like an extended autumn. Our garage, nestled at the back of the house, is a hub of activity, especially when I'm tinkering with my truck or other projects. When the garage doors are open, I feel a sense of connection to the neighborhood. On holidays, the neighborhood takes on a more subdued tone, with the occasional visit from out-of-town guests and the presence of extra cars. It's a peaceful, if not perfect, life – if only it weren't a through street, it would be ideal.

Living in my neighborhood is an experience that's hard to put into words unless you've actually been there. Tucked away in the high desert, it's a world of endless brown landscapes and the occasional perfectly manicured lawn that's a testament to the owner's dedication to lawn care. I've been a resident here since the 90s, and I've seen the area change. What was once a sprawling expanse of houses now has a more urban feel, with new additions sprouting up left and right. It's a paradox - while it's starting to feel more like a city, it's not uncommon for places to undergo similar transformations.

Despite the changes, my neighborhood remains a welcoming community. I'm surrounded by friendly faces, and for the most part, the atmosphere is pleasant. However, like any city, there are its drawbacks. The local stores are mostly chain establishments, and if you're looking for a more upscale experience, you're out of luck - unless you're willing to drive further afield. The local economy is dominated by the construction industry, which isn't surprising given the vast open spaces still waiting to be developed. It's a bit unsettling, to be honest, as I left behind the hustle and bustle of a big city and prefer things just the way they are.

As for me, I'm a drywall and T-bar installer, and I've seen firsthand the impact of construction on our community. When I'm not working, I enjoy the unique wildlife that calls the high desert home. People come to this unforgiving yet breathtaking environment for a reason - it's a challenging ecosystem that demands respect and understanding. As residents, it's essential to learn about the non-human inhabitants of our surroundings to coexist peacefully. My kids are particularly fascinated by the desert creatures, and as I write this, they're outside trying to catch them. 

In terms of attractions, Victorville has its share. If you're planning a visit, consider timing it with the annual San Bernardino County Fair, which offers a unique blend of activities and entertainment. Just a short drive away lies Wrightwood, where you can experience the thrill of winter sports on the snow-capped mountains. For those interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert, the Victor Valley Museum is a treasure trove of geological, paleontological, and historical artifacts that tell the story of Victorville's development and growth.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, my response is likely to be a bit unconventional. Unlike most people, who might think of a neighborhood as a collection of homes and local businesses within a specific geographic area, I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus I reside on, along with the people who live in my dormitory. I also extend that definition to the surrounding campus, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this unique perspective, my neighborhood shares some familiar characteristics with more traditional neighborhoods. Like any other neighborhood, it has a mix of residences, people from diverse backgrounds, stores, and public spaces.

Let's start by exploring the "houses" that make up my neighborhood. To clarify, there are three main types of housing in my immediate area: apartments, houses, and dormitories. The apartments typically accommodate 2-4 people per room and have 4-6 rooms on each floor, with a total of 20 or so residents in each building. The houses available for rent to people affiliated with the school are usually 2-4 bedroom setups, often occupied by alumni. These are relatively rare, however, as they're not as efficient as other housing options. The most common type of housing is the dormitory, where hundreds of students live in shared rooms, often with two people per room, except in a few exceptions.

Moving on to the people who call my neighborhood home, it's a melting pot of cultures and ages. Most professional staff reside in the houses, while newer students live in dorms, and older students opt for apartment-style housing. The diversity of my neighborhood is a testament to my school's commitment to inclusivity. To do justice to the people who live here, I'll skip directly to the stores and parks in my neighborhood. Given that my school is essentially a self-contained community, it's equipped with a variety of stores, including dining options, school-branded clothing and grocery stores, and anything else one might need within the neighborhood's boundaries. The park, a playground for all residents, is well-maintained and safe, thanks to the collective efforts of my neighborhood's diverse community.

As someone who has lived in this neighborhood for over a decade, I've gained a unique perspective that I feel comfortable sharing. My initial move here from Riverdale to Stockbridge was a tough one. I have to admit, I was heartbroken, missing the familiarity of my old neighborhood and the friends I left behind. However, my parents made the decision to relocate for a better life, better schools, and a safer environment. Over time, I adapted to my new surroundings, formed new friendships, and even encountered some acquaintances that turned into adversaries in school. Despite having lived here for so long, I've never truly taken the time to get to know my neighbors, except for a few notable exceptions - Mr. Glen and his family, who live next door, and Dennis, who lived nearby for a while. They've become like family to me, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. I vividly remember attending Mr. Glen's wedding (his remarriage) - it was an unforgettable experience, and I look forward to one day having a similar celebration with my own future wife. A particularly memorable moment from the wedding was when I caught the stray white strap from Ms. Veda's leg, although I didn't quite catch the bouquet! The night was filled with laughter, music, and great company, especially with Marsharii, one of Mr. Glen's daughters. I've lost touch with her, but I hope she's thriving in her endeavors. This neighborhood can be a bit confusing, but with the help of GPS, I've been able to explore it more thoroughly. I've spent time with friends Kason and Curtis, engaging in friendly competitions and sharing life's joys. We'd often play video games, and I'd also visit the park to connect with nature and find solace in its tranquility. It's become a sanctuary for me, a place where I can unwind and recharge. Occasionally, I'd visit the park with sticks from Home Depot to practice my balance, and I even brought my bokken wooden sword along. The basketball and tennis courts are also nearby, although I haven't picked up a racket or ball in a while. However, they're still there, waiting for me to rediscover my passion for these sports. My dad taught me and my best friend tennis with Mr. Graves, and we always had a great time, even when they pushed us to our limits. As I look back on my time here, I'm reminded of the many happy moments I've experienced. There are countless stories, but these memories stand out to me, and I'm excited to see what the future holds for this neighborhood and for myself.

I'm grateful to live in an area that's close to the college I attend. The proximity to campus is one of the reasons I enjoy my neighborhood. The landscape is predominantly made up of apartment complexes, which are complemented by a few restaurants and bars that are both affordable and entertaining. One of the bars recently got a new name, but it's a bit pricier than the others, which are more budget-friendly. Despite this, the service and drinks are still decent, and the crowd is generally friendly. They're mostly comprised of college students or individuals from lower-income backgrounds, as the apartment complexes are reasonably priced. The area is also home to a number of families, thanks to the presence of an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don't really know my neighbors, which suits me just fine, considering they're known to be heavy smokers, and the management of my building has installed an air freshener unit outside their door – a move that I find amusing, if a bit condescending. The neighboring buildings are mostly old, but some have undergone renovations, which is a relief. However, down the street, there are brand-new apartments that I'm not too fond of, as I've heard their construction quality is subpar, but the rent is steep. The developers seem to be taking advantage of the area's proximity to the university to charge exorbitant rates. For affordable and quick eats, there's a restaurant nearby that serves meals on paper plates, with most of their offerings being microwaved. Across the street is a gas station that's apparently not a great place to work. Fortunately, a recent city-funded renovation has improved the area's infrastructure, with a newly paved road, widened sidewalks, and lush greenery on the medians and road sides. My apartment complex is surrounded by trees, although some have been recently pruned, leaving behind stumps. The area behind my complex is lined with trees, and just beyond that, another set of apartments stands. While I live on 42nd street, the street behind mine – 43rd – is less desirable, with crumbling sidewalks and worn-down buildings. The only redeeming feature of this street is its abundance of trees, which might be an attempt to mask its shortcomings. Most of the crime in the area seems to stem from an apartment complex on 43rd, although it's unfair to single them out, as there are other apartments across from me with a history of issues and a transient population. Still, I'm content with my living situation. The rent is manageable, and I appreciate the convenient access to the university, as well as the two bus stops nearby that make it easy to get to the store and the downtown area.

My neighborhood is a charming cluster of duplexes located on a quiet cul-de-sac, giving the illusion of individual houses. Each one boasts a vibrant yellow exterior, complete with a crisp white porch and a green metal roof. While most, but not all, of the residents have become close friends, we still manage to gather at the end of the cul-de-sac on some evenings, watching as the children play and laugh together. It's a refreshing respite from the fast-paced world of technology and machinery that surrounds us in our daily lives. The setting is reminiscent of a simpler, bygone era, with fields and trees stretching as far as the eye can see, under a brilliant blue sky with puffy white clouds. However, the changing seasons bring their own set of challenges, and this time around, we've experienced our first tornado warning, complete with the eerie sound of sirens and a sudden, dramatic drop in temperature. 

I found myself huddled in my bathtub with my youngest dog and a few essentials, while my larger dog remained in the living room, anxious and barking in the background. The neighborhood was eerily quiet, except for the sound of hail pounding against the ground. After the storm passed, the road was steaming hot, a stark reminder of the drastic temperature shift – 92 degrees plummeted to 75 in a matter of minutes. As the sun broke through the clearing skies, a brilliant rainbow appeared, and I rushed inside to grab my camera to capture the breathtaking sight. The streets remained deserted for a while, until the residents returned home from wherever they were when the storm hit, and then it was back to the usual evening routine – moms and children playing outside while dinner cooked. It's been a delightful discovery for a transplant like myself, who's moved from New Hampshire to North Carolina. I've grown to appreciate the warm, welcoming accents of my neighbors, and I've found solace in the fact that, despite our identical-looking apartments, each one has its own unique character. Some are surprisingly cozy, while others are more spacious. I love taking long walks through the largest field behind my home, meandering down to the serene pond that's perfect for taking in the sights and sounds of nature. It's a haven, just 40 minutes outside the bustling city of Charlotte. Each morning begins with the cheerful sound of roosters crowing from the surrounding farms, making it feel like I'm living in a quaint village. We're also treated to the soothing sounds of a nearby donkey's evening bray, a constant reminder of the peaceful atmosphere that pervades our little community. I feel incredibly fortunate to have stumbled upon this hidden gem of a neighborhood.

I remember the day I moved into this neighborhood like it was yesterday, right on the eve of eighth grade. It wasn't easy making friends at first, but I eventually found solace in the company of a neighbor who lived just two houses down and another classmate who lived on the same street. Although they're no longer around, the memories we shared remain vivid in my mind. What's striking is how little has changed since I first moved in - the same families still reside in this neighborhood, giving it a sense of stability and continuity. Our neighborhood looks like many other American suburbs, with rows of two-story houses and an atmosphere that's quintessentially suburban. Every weekend, the sound of children playing outside is a familiar soundtrack, and most days are remarkably quiet. I've never had any issues with the neighbors, and that's a testament to the trust that exists here. My packages have been safely delivered to my doorstep without a hitch, and I feel a sense of security knowing my neighbors have my back. A park just a minute or two away from my home holds a special place in my heart, where I've spent countless hours playing basketball, football, and baseball with the other kids in the neighborhood. While I also have a painful memory of getting elbowed in the nose during a football game, the good times far outweigh the bad. Now, whenever I visit the park, it's with my cousin's energetic kids, who love to swing and slide. The park now brings back a flood of nostalgia for a bygone era. Our neighborhood is a melting pot, with a diverse range of cuisines available just a short walk away. You can find everything from Chinese to Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants within a one-mile radius. However, with the rise of food delivery apps like GrubHub and DoorDash, many of us have opted for the convenience of having our meals delivered. Fast food joints are, of course, a staple in any suburban neighborhood, but we have a few local pizza places that are worth mentioning. The stores here cater to all our needs, with multiple dry cleaners, a Walgreens, a CVS, and a Jewel-Osco grocery store that's a staple in the Midwest. There's even an Indian-owned store where you can find everything from ingredients to ready-made meals. Given the horror stories I've seen on social media and the news about neighbors from other parts of the country, I'm grateful for the neighborhood I call home.

You've probably driven through Johnston, South Carolina, without giving it a second glance. It's a charming little town nestled in the heart of the state, not standing out from the rest, but quietly making its mark on the agriculture sector. Known as the Peach Capital of the World, Johnston proudly wears this title on its sleeve – literally – as a welcome sign greets visitors. The town's landscape is dominated by farmland, with peach trees and cattle grazing in the fields. Homes are scattered throughout, most of them two-story affairs with metal roofs to shield against the scorching summer heat or gray shingles to blend in with the surroundings. Many of these homes are tucked away from the main road, allowing the front fields to be used for livestock or crops. The central part of town is barely a hub, with a single stoplight controlling the four-way intersection where the few local businesses are concentrated. Residents have a choice of a handful of eateries, including Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. The absence of a pizzeria is a recent loss, but the town still has a quaint family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug, which is surprisingly famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola. Shoppers can find the essentials at Independent Grocers Alliance, or IGA, the only grocery store in town, although many prefer to make the short drive to a larger Walmart in a nearby town for their grocery needs. Dollar General is the town's most popular store, bustling from opening to closing time with daily essentials and miscellaneous items. For furniture shopping, residents head to Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind-hearted woman who has been a fixture in the community for years and even offers delivery services. The store is conveniently attached to a pet groomers, Clark's Cuts and Kennels, which offers a range of services for furry friends. Medical care is available in the form of a small doctor's and veterinary practice, both located outside of the main town area. The town's only elementary school, Johnston Elementary, serves the younger residents, while middle and high school students head to the next town over. Although there's a lack of recreational activities, the town is currently working on a 2.5-acre recreational area to cater to families and attract more visitors. Despite its limited attractions, Johnston is a pleasant town that can easily go unnoticed when driving through.

The first time I heard about my neighborhood, it was while listening to a podcast about people who had vanished without a trace. It was a surprising revelation, considering that nearly every apartment in the area was renting for over $1,000 a month. I had never heard anything about that story before, and neither had any of my friends. Perhaps it's a reflection of our own struggles; we've all learned to live with the bare essentials over the years. It's not uncommon for people to cry themselves to sleep at night, weighed down by the crushing expense of living. However, we've adapted to the grind, learning to appreciate the simpler things in life. You start to develop a fondness for the musty scent of second-hand toys and moth-eaten clothing. Adulthood may not smell as sweet, but we've grown accustomed to the stale air that fills our days. Some turn to smoking as a coping mechanism, while others simply accept the status quo. Yet, amidst the drudgery, a glimmer of authenticity remains. This neighborhood is a testament to that – a place where thrift stores thrive, and the sounds of the city fade away. There are three thrift stores within walking distance, each one a haven for those seeking refuge from the chaos outside. You can escape the cacophony of the city and lose yourself in their silence. As the downtown area continues to grow, with its e-commerce empires and congested streets, our neighborhood remains a tranquil oasis. It's a place where people can be alone, yet still feel connected to their community. We may not know each other's stories, but we respect our boundaries and let each other be. It's a refreshing change from the South, where being inquisitive is seen as a sign of caring. In our neighborhood, people are content to keep to themselves, and the city hums along, a gentle melody of strangers becoming friends. The sounds of the city are a distant memory when you're surrounded by the sounds of your neighbors – the pianist next door, the amateur vocalists upstairs, and the occasional chatter. It's not uncommon for us to come together to celebrate birthdays, mourn losses, and lend a helping hand. I feel fortunate to be a part of this community, where my neighbors have become my friends. We take turns leaving food on the doorstep, collecting mail, and respecting each other's space. It's a beautiful thing, really – a reminder that even in the midst of a sprawling, impersonal city, human connection can thrive.

Living in my area, you'll find the quintessential suburban landscape that's more or less a carbon copy of the rest. My neighborhood is a prime example of this, with a homeowner's association exerting its influence throughout. Every home is meticulously maintained, thanks to the HOA's efforts. The lawns are all neatly manicured, with small trees and decorative pebbles adding a touch of uniformity. Each driveway is similarly trimmed, with two-car garages being the norm. The streets are a testament to the HOA's dedication to order, with newly paved concrete stretching as far as the eye can see. You won't find any potholes or rough patches here. Architecturally, the homes are predominantly single-story, although some two-story houses can be spotted here and there. One peculiarity is the mail system, which deviates from the traditional single-family mailbox setup. Instead, residents share a large cluster of mailboxes at the end of the street, accessible only with a key. This, too, is a result of the HOA's emphasis on uniformity. My neighborhood is situated on the outskirts of the city, making it a blend of rural and suburban landscapes. This unique setting provides ample space for leisure activities, including multiple community pools and walking trails. These amenities are well-maintained and gated, allowing residents to enjoy the great outdoors without needing to venture into a park. The neighborhood is substantial enough that one can easily get a good workout by simply walking or running around it. The community is comprised mainly of retirees, creating a safe and watchful environment. However, it's not exclusive, as younger professionals and middle-aged individuals also reside here. The nearby city, while large in terms of population, has a cozily small-town feel. One would expect to find most amenities here, including a modest mall that caters to the community's needs. For those who prefer shopping, it's only a 15-minute drive to reach the city center, where an array of stores awaits. From high-end grocery stores to bargain outlets, residents have access to a wide range of shopping options. In summary, my neighborhood is a safe, well-maintained, and relatively typical community, offering many comforts like pools and walking trails, and with the added convenience of easy access to shopping and amenities.

I reside in a small Midwestern town that nestles at the outskirts of a bustling metropolis. My immediate neighborhood, situated on the eastern side of town, is a microcosm of the area's economic disparities. Housing values are relatively low, with most homes rented or owned by low-income families. Yet, this doesn't translate to a visually unappealing or unpleasant environment. My neighbors are a friendly bunch who exchange warm smiles and greetings as I stroll down the street. While crime rates are marginally higher than in other areas, they remain relatively low. Over the past decade, there have been a few violent incidents within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and a homicide. A shooting outside a local bar claimed the life of our next-door neighbors' son just last year. Fortunately, our family hasn't been directly impacted by crime, aside from the occasional stolen item left on our porch when we forget to bring it inside. The town has been severely impacted by the nationwide "opioid epidemic," claiming numerous lives due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, our community boasts a wealth of resources to combat this issue, including addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and loved ones affected by addiction. Amidst these challenges, my town has its redeeming qualities. My son's elementary school boasts an exceptional staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite his special needs, he's been spared the brunt of bullying, thanks to the school's positive atmosphere, which he adores. Our active PTO organizes multiple events to foster family involvement and educational growth. Given that over 20% of our town's population struggles below the poverty line, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry. No child or family is perceived as inferior due to financial constraints, and school fees, supplies, and field trips are reasonably priced. The City Council and staff have implemented various improvements to our town's appearance, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these upgrades have been concentrated in the town center and on the west side, where shopping areas and major traffic flow through. My neighborhood on the east side tends to be overlooked, a point of contention for my community. Despite these disparities, I genuinely enjoy living in this town. The residents are generally friendly, the schools excel, there are ample shopping options to meet my family's needs, and while our home may not be valuable, it's comfortable and suitable for us. After 16 years, my family cannot envision living anywhere else.

My neighborhood is a vibrant cultural hub, nestled on a hill surrounded by historic buildings that hold stories of the past. I reside in a 7-story apartment complex directly across from a century-old theater and just a block away from a charming arcade bar that draws in a diverse crowd on warm summer evenings. During peak season, you'll often find a line of people waiting to get in, eager to experience the excitement. A short walk up the hill lies the city's largest park, which is surprisingly spacious considering its location. The park is encircled by a concrete wall with steep stairs that lead down to the sidewalk. In the harsh winter months, the homeless population sets up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and stairs, providing some sense of community and shared warmth. Although it doesn't snow much in this region, the torrential rain during the mid-winter months can make it difficult to stay warm. By clustering their tents together in the heart of town, they can at least stay relatively warm and have access to essential services like the nearby family center, where they can shower and bathe.

What I love about my neighborhood, however, goes beyond its historic charm and architectural beauty. It's the people who truly make this place special. Hilltop, once infamous for gang violence, still carries a reputation that lingers even decades later. Stories of federal interventions and DEA raids are still shared among residents, passed down through generations, and even shared with newcomers like myself. Despite its tough reputation, the community works hard to keep the neighborhood clean and respectable. They care deeply about their city and their block, and it's clear that they've learned to look out for one another. The warning to outsiders to avoid walking alone at night may seem like a relic of the past, but it's a testament to the lingering effects of social conditioning and racism. Perhaps it's because I've learned to navigate the world in a way that allows me to blend in, or maybe Hilltop has adopted me as one of their own. Whatever the reason, I know that I'm not just a visitor – I'm a part of this community. I feel alive at night, walking the streets and encountering people who have shown me kindness and generosity. Strangers have offered me a jacket when I needed one, or stayed open late to let me charge my phone in the rain. It's a place where I've felt invisible, huddled against concrete storefronts on cold, grey nights, only to be approached by someone who's seen me, looked me in the eye, and told me I'm beautiful and valuable. These moments remind me that, no matter where life takes me, Hilltop will always be home.

I call Rural America home, specifically a charming small town in Michigan. Nestled between farmland and quaint tourist cities, our community lacks the hustle and bustle of big city life, with no sprawling malls, superstores, or chain restaurants like Applebee's to be found. Every outing requires a drive, yet I'm fortunate to reside in one of the most breathtaking regions in the world, surrounded by the tranquility of water. My 'city' is literally surrounded by water – the majestic Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Every turn reveals a beach, beckoning you to dip your toes in its refreshing waters. The neighborhood I live in echoes the quintessential small-town ambiance. Houses sprawl out, each unique in its own right, without the cookie-cutter uniformity of newer developments. Many have been lovingly updated and remodeled, while others remain timeless and true to their original charm. Most homes boast spacious basements, fully visible from the road, and a colorful array of aluminum siding adorns the streets. One house stands out from the next, with a delightful medley of colors and architectural styles. Yards abound, showcasing family life with trampolines, playsets, and gardens. You'll see fences for pets, evidence of hardworking families who've dedicated themselves to providing for their loved ones. On any given day, you'll spot kids racing up and down the sidewalks, while neighbors walk their dogs, bike, or rollerblade. Friendliness is palpable here – a smile and a wave can be exchanged with a fellow neighbor from across the street, or with someone who's walking their dog from a few blocks away. Lawns are well-manicured, with neatly trimmed bushes and green grass that stretches as far as the eye can see. It's not a neighborhood that will leave you awestruck with its grandeur, but rather one that exudes a sense of comfort and belonging – a safe haven where families can thrive. Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department and jail, a testament to the community's commitment to law and order. The local health department and recycling center are nearby, providing essential services to residents. The air is filled with the sounds of happy children playing baseball and softball at the nearby fields, while the hum of small planes taking off and landing at the local airport creates a soothing background noise. On a warm day, the local ice cream shop is just a short stroll away, and the downtown area is within easy reach for those who want to explore further. My kids can ride their bikes to the park in just a few short blocks, making this a truly idyllic place to call home.

original_texts:
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets.
